page.title: 10CONSERVATION AND THE FARMER
page.content: During the late 197Os the people of the area were involved in disputes concerning land-use. As a result of this the Alkham Valley Preservation Society was established. A farmer, new to the valley, decided to clear scrubland so that he could recultivate the higher slopes. Trees were felled and hedges were grubbed out. The Society managed to get a preservation order on the trees but much damage had already been done. The results can be seen in the valley today. The areas of high ground around Sladden Wood and Oak Wood reveal soil erosion and the effect of wind-blow and wind-snap on exposed trees. The area proved unsuitable for modern farming and the majority of the population hope that in due course the area will revert to scrubland.
